awd_titl_txt: Partial Support of the Committee on Astronomy and Astrophysics
awd_abstract_narration:
The U.S. National Academy of Sciences will continue its support of the activities of the Committee on Astronomy and Astrophysics (CAA).  Using the astronomy and astrophysics decadal surveys, the CAA identifies issues of concern to the astronomy and astrophysics community and provides guidance to federal agencies regarding their astronomy and astrophysics research programs in order to encourage the field’s scientific progress.  The committee membership itself is drawn from experts across the astronomy and astrophysics disciplines and as such is able to identify and assess issues and trends which impact the broader multidisciplinary arena.

The CAA has a broad impact by acting as an established forum to bring together leading researchers from the scientific community and representatives from across the federal government to discuss emerging research needs and opportunities for the advancement of astronomy and astrophysics.  In each ad hoc study that the CAA initiates and oversees, the committee places an emphasis on accessibility by the layperson and promoting the public understanding of science. By identifying cross-cutting issues and/or opportunities, the CAA can enhance the research and education environment.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Committee on Astronomy and Astrophysics (CAA) is a joint initiative of the National Academies’ Space Studies Board and the Board on Physics and Astronomy. The committee plays a critical role in advancing the fields of astronomy and astrophysics by:

  • Monitoring the health of physics and astronomy research;
  • Identifying emerging scientific developments;
  • Strengthening connections between astronomy, technology, and other scientific fields;
  • Facilitating national and international research coordination;
  • Encouraging cooperation among federal agencies, government laboratories, and universities;
  • Enhancing public understanding of space science and policy; and
  • Promoting communication between the research community, federal agencies, and the public.

Scope and Purpose

The CAA’s overarching mission is to support scientific progress in astronomy and astrophysics and assist the federal government in planning and integrating programs in these fields. The committee’s work spans the full spectrum of astronomy and astrophysics research, covering both space- and ground-based observations. Its domain includes:

  • Stellar, galactic, and extragalactic astronomy;
  • Particle astrophysics and cosmology;
  • The search for exoplanets; and
  • Fundamental physics aspects related to astronomical objects.

Additionally, the CAA examines cross-disciplinary topics and programmatic and budgetary considerations related to the implementation of the decadal survey.

Decadal Survey Implementation and Oversight

A key responsibility of the CAA is monitoring progress in implementing the recommendations of the 2020 Decadal Survey on Astronomy and Astrophysics (Astro2020), titled Pathways to Discovery in Astronomy and Astrophysics for the 2020s. Published during the reporting period, Astro2020 sets the research priorities and strategic vision for the next decade.

Beyond monitoring, the CAA plays a central role in shaping future research by overseeing the development of studies impacting the astronomy and astrophysics communities. It also serves as the primary body within the National Academies involved in planning the next decadal survey.

Independent Study: Roman Space Telescope

During this reporting period, the CAA conducted an independent, committee-led study titled Roman Space Telescope Observing Time Allocation Principles. This study provided timely guidance on setting policies for allocating observing time on the Nancy Grace Roman Space Telescope, a major upcoming mission. The full report is publicly available for free download at www.nap.edu.

Engagement and Policy Monitoring

To stay informed on policy and scientific developments, the CAA maintains ongoing interactions with federal representatives, scientists, and mission/facility leaders. Throughout this funding cycle, the CAA convened:

  • Five in-person meetings featuring open sessions attended by members of the public, and
  • Twelve teleconference meetings to facilitate discussions on emerging topics.

Public Accessibility and Outreach

The CAA maintains a public website at National Academies - CAA, which provides:

  • The committee’s statement of task;
  • A list of upcoming and past meetings/events;
  • Information on committee members and staff;
  • Presentations from past meetings;
  • Details on related report-writing activities;
  • A link to the Space Studies Board website; and
  • Acknowledgment of sponsorship from NASA and NSF.

The CAA remains committed to supporting scientific progress, fostering collaboration, and guiding the future of astronomy and astrophysics research through its work with the National Academies, government agencies, and the broader scientific community.
